I landed an engineering job a little while ago for a large corporation. The single biggest frustration so far has nothing to do with the actual work.

I seem to require special permissions from information security to do literally anything ever. Oftentimes this makes a project that I could complete in day, stretch out for weeks. Probably 90% of my office hours are spent doing nothing because I'm not allowed to do my job.

The other big frustration is different people preventing me from finishing something by having conflicting expectations. A common occurrence is there will be something that could be solved in an extremely straightforward way and then someone will finally get around to reviewing my PR for it a week later and be like, "Oh no, anon, we definitely can't do it that way. Instead we should do this mindfuckingly convoluted way instead that will add an extra two weeks to the task despite offering no advantages that I'm going to articulate to you." Okay, fine, so I'd that instead, wait again for someone to review it, someone else gives helpful comments, I fix it, wait yet again, and then have someone else say something like, "Hey why in the world would you do that when there are much simpler approaches? >>91568425
You could even set a web page as your desktop wallpaper (ie. Active Desktop.) Was really neat when it worked.

The main problem with either is neither ActiveX nor any of it's clones (eg. KDE KParts) ever really solved process isolation, so one web page hanging (which was really common back in the day) could hang your entire desktop, and of course it was a security nightmare too. And Active Desktop could prevent the desktop from loading in the first place, forcing you to go into safe mode and disable it.

It could probably be brought back now with CEF/WebView2, but file manager and browser UIs have diverged too much imo.

The captcha request's Cloudflare gateway no longer accepts Android webview with its default user-agent. Kuroba-dev was already using a custom user-agent so it didn't break. Web browser works as it can be disambiguated from a webview via various headers which aren't user-agent.

>>91572205
use an inpainting model, set to only masked
you can lower the resolution when you do that because it will inpaint at whatever you set and then scale it down to fit into the masked area. no need to do like 1024x1024 just for a face

also remember to remove prompts that don't have anything to do with what you're inpainting. for example, you don't need clothing or body tags while inpainting a face

>>91530783
Don't lecture me. I am not basing my argument off the fact that I can prove it in this instance, but that it has been proven in previous instances. A convicted child molester would be barred from taking care of children because of his past actions, not because you can now prove that he does something immoral. The same applies to Big Tech companies.

In addition to that, burden of proof applies in fields where epistemology is unhindered, that is in science, journalism and law. That's where knowledge is (ideally) openly shared. When it comes to corporations and secret services, then we have a wall of silence and disinformation to deceive the intelligence gathering of competitors. Under such circumstances I find it absolutely grotesque to appeal to the burden of proof, when even the most well meaning attempts to gather proof are hindered in such a way. Or to put it differently: "You can't prove what secret services are doing? You are wrong!" - ridiculous and absurdly retarded.

>>91570839
Pipewire itself isn't doing any resampling, that is done in the PulseAudio wrappers for most users. The resampler quality can be changed in /etc/pipewire/client.conf and /etc/pipewire/pipewire-pulse.conf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91570890

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91571305
Kind of agree with you, but the trouble is that there isn't really a one-size-fits-all answer. Resampling is imperfect and has a definite CPU usage/quality tradeoff. (and probably a latency one too depending on how many taps you want)

PulseAudio had bumped down to a worse speex resampler in the past specifically because of issues with CPU usage being too high in a lot of circumstances. The quality level of the resampler they chose was OK; it was normally audibly transparent, but you could actually get some pretty bad aliasing if you had some very high frequencies in your waveforms. I believe it is still like this by default.

They tend to favor lower CPU usage by default because otherwise users who don't care about audio quality as long as it's transparent on their shitty headphones. maybe it should try to be adaptive but that does seem kind of complicated

The inconvenient answer is that applications should probably deal with it. I think that is the intent with Pipewire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91556032
>Can you provide some concrete example of how it is a clusterfuck without pasting some link of a blog from 10 years ago?
In PHP, the function to split a string by a delimiter is called explode(). It has this stupid name because the original split() was a regex split and since most of the language builtins share one global function namespace they had to pick a different name for a non-regex delimiter split. Eventually split() was deprecated in favor of preg_split(). There's also "str_split()" which splits a string into an array given a chunk size.

So PHP now has three string-splitting functions that all have stupid names because the language is, has been, and always will be a clusterfuck.

It's single threaded and the variables are loosely typed so you kind of need to rely on a IDE to make sure your code is sane and use only === comparisons with type checks. For example a dumb gotcha is

$name = "faggot";
if(!strpos($name, "faggot")) {
  // 0 and false match !

}

if(strpos($name, "faggot") === false) {
  // false means no match
}

>>91564964
You're trying to interpret arbitrary binary data as text, which is why you get garbage. You would be better served using a hex editor, but as you are a self-admitted retard, I don't think that will be very helpful for you.

You're either going to need to get a hold of the source code, or reverse engineer the game to understand the save file format. Both of which are probably out of your reach.

Learn to code, get good. Stop being a retard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91564964
this is a binary file, open it in a hex editor and see what you can make of it.
It might simply be a dotNet binary serialization, if that's the case the best option would be to use ILSpy to take apart the game's dotNet DLL to see how it's loading this.
From there you could then hack the file in a hex editor to get the value you want, or possibly modify the game's DLL so it saves and loads JSON files instead which are easier to edit by hand.
Another option would be to copy the class that gets serialized into your own C# project and write a Winforms program that lets you modify and then save it yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91558554
Clicking smaller things in a higher resolution screen has a high risk of misclicking, so I need to slow down. Big square buttons means I can lazily kinda throw my mouse in their general direction and still get it right, so it's faster even if it's further away. Which is the whole point of Fitts' law as they say on the blog:

"The farther away a target is, the longer it takes to acquire it with a mouse
The smaller a target is, the longer it takes to acquire it with a mouse"

Fitts' law is also the reason for Apple's global menu among other things, so it's not something Microsoft came up with to justify the start screen. Anyway, that is not my point. The point is that the new Windows 11 start menu has the green items way above the recommended items, while being smaller, which makes them harder to click than even the start menu of old. It's a massive regression and despite me looking for it, I have never seen Microsoft justify it anywhere.
